Topic.Title: Windows 8 is what is killing PC's

Message.Msg: Yes from talking to friends and others, some who are responsible for upgrading their company's systems. What I'm hearing is they are waiting for at least a fix of windows 8 to purchase. Most say if you have a touch screen it isn't so bad. Microsoft should of not forced 8 on non touch PC's. I saw a article that said Microsoft's earnings were hurt by the decline in PC sales, but they are the ones who contributed to that decline.

Topic.Title: Windows 8 is what is killing PC's

Message.Msg: Arrogance has killed many a company. It could happen to Microsoft...or to Intel. You've got to listen to your customers and give them what they want. This is true even for Apple who thinks the customer will buy whatever they're selling. Maybe was true once, not any more. Customers want cheap chips; the chips don't have to be the 'best'. Not everyone drives a Mercedes to work, a Chevy gets the job done just as well for much less money. If the chips are the best and they're price competitive, so much the better. I think Intel finally gets the picture. I just hope it's not too late.

Topic.Title: Windows 8 is what is killing PC's

Message.Msg: BS. People want performance that is cost effective. Long battery life is a big, big plus. So too is a very brief instant to reboot or wake-up. And since software gets less and less efficient, people want speed. With greater performance will come mush greater versatility. We haven't scratched the surface of these possibilities. It's not a one-dimensional space, like your mind. But Windows 8 simply sux. And that is the large pos that is clogging up the plumbing now, like your posts.

Topic.Title: Windows 8 is what is killing PC's

Message.Msg: The guys that write software target the installed base which is typically one generation behind in performance to the latest platforms. Adoption of more performant platforms is therefore not always a given. This is why for example Intel increased battery life with Haswell and not performance.

Topic.Title: Windows 8 is what is killing PC's

Message.Msg: I doubt you know what people 'want'. Or what the companies that make the machines want. Did Microsoft know what people wanted? Did they care? If they did and they cared, where did Windows 8 come from. If Intel makes the 'best performing' chips, why is Apple dealing with Samsung or TMSC? There are many considerations other than brute performance. And there always will be. Arrogance kills companies. Moron.

Topic.Title: Windows 8 is what is killing PC's

Message.Msg: This is absolutely true. Windows 8 was designed for tablets and is abysmal for traditional desktops and laptops. How Microsoft believed forcing W8 & Metro on traditional desktops and laptops was a good idea is beyond belief. And many people don't like the security vulnerabilities Microsoft creates by pushing ads to Metro tiles as well as Microsoft's insistence in pushing its SkyDrive cloud on users. I know businesses that had planned to buy new PC's since the beginning of the year but refused to bring Windows 8 into their shops. Instead they are postponing their purchases, installing Linux wherever they can and some are buying MACs. Windows 8.1 preview seems to suggest a some improvement but so far it doesn't go far enough to correct everything wrong with W8 and the traditional PC market. Microsoft's is singlehandedly responsible for destroying much of the demand for traditional PCs.

Topic.Title: If Baytrail Ipads get 10-12 hr battery life, and ARM based Ipads get 7 hrs

Message.Msg: Actually, the iPads get either 9 hour or 10 hour battery life according to Apple website. But nevertheless, Intel based Mac Book Airs with powerful Haswell processors get 9 hour for the 11 inch version and 12 hour for 13 inch version. Looks like nothing left for ARM to boast about. Intel has definitely beat ARM in power consumption. Baytrail that is due for Holidays will actually be more efficient for smaller form factors in computing.

Message.Title: Question regarding Baytrail
Message.Msg: According to Bohr 22nm SoC can come in different flavors; the way I understand it can have 8 to 12 layers of copper interconnect. IOW this SoC can cover a "range" of tablets with different price/performance points and therefore the statement Baytrail would "cannibalize" Haswell is incoorect. Only the version with 12 metal layer version could challenge Haswell while the "cheaper" versions go directly against ARM. Also Bohr said both (SoC and CPU) can be manufactured side by side; therefore I think the 22nm SoCs currently manufactured should have very good yields right out the gate. So Intel actually builds Chevy SoCs and BMW SoCs. Do I see this correctly?

Topic.Title: Question regarding Baytrail

Message.Msg: You are seeing it correctly. Also keep in mind that the Haswell and upcoming Broadwell micro-architectures target fundamentally different performance levels on both CPU and GPU. The top Haswell GPU SKU has 40 EUs, while the top Baytrail SKU has 4 EUs. On CPU, while Baytrail will come with up to 4 cores, per core Haswell is significantly more sophisticated (much deeper and wider OoO engine, L3$, and beefier execution units). There will be very little cannibalization. Baytrail is a small die aimed for low power and low cost, Haswell is significantly higher performance aimed at higher power envelopes. Broadwell, however, could be a problem for Baytrail on the power side of things as the 14nm shrink + 2nd gen FinFETs will allow Broadwell to go into

Topic.Title: If Baytrail Ipads get 10-12 hr battery life, and ARM based Ipads get 7 hrs

Message.Msg: Just for you, Mr Smartbutt. PC world review of IPad has this to say. How much of the new iPad's battery drain is attributable to its beefier processor and how much is due to the brighter, higher-resolution display is unclear. Our colleagues at Macworld performed battery-life tests at full brightness and at 150 cd/m2, and the new iPad consistently ran for a shorter period than the iPad 2 did. In Macworld's tests, the new iPad at full brightness ran for one-third less time than its predecessor did, lasting 5 hours, 40 minutes to the iPad 2's 8 hours, 30 minutes. At 150 cd/m2, the difference was a bit smaller, but still significant--the new iPad's battery lasted 10 hours, 10 minutes, versus the iPad 2's running time of 13 hours, 20 minutes.

Topic.Title: 7/19/2011 - INTC is $21.50 per share adj. for dividends

Message.Msg: " If you wait and must sell when it goes lower you technically lose your dividend and your principal." This is sort of true for every NON-CASH investment. If you have a short term need for the cash, it is wrong to take more risk than you can afford. Duh!! You clearly don't understand what a Ponzi scheme is or you would not call Intel a Ponzi scheme. Your "wait for the bottom" strategy is rather simple minded and does not apply to investors nor many medium time frame traders. Example .... I also took A PORTION of my portfolio dedicated to LIQUID CASH and dedicate to Intel . When Intel drops down near $20-$22, I get shares and when it goes above $25, it tends to get sold. Intel is very liquid and yields are well above the sub-1% that savings is yielding. IN ADDITION to the "3.75% return per year", I take and sell $25 call options on the next QUARTERLY $25 call option. Today the Oct $25 call options are selling for 33 cents. That is an additional 11 cents per month. When the $25 stock gets ASSIGNED, I start selling $23 PUT options which are about $2 out of the money. It would be like selling an OCT $21 PUT option today. which are going for 48 cents. When the Intel price goes down, the put option premium I receive gets higher than the 48 cents and is usually double. The PUT options are a little higher than the calls since they are affected by the dividend. During that time, I don't get the dividend directly but partially through the put option. The dividend is about 7 cents per month and the options are about 10 cents per month so 17 cents per month on an investment of "$21.50" is $2.04 or 9.4%. For some, a steady 9.4% yield is pretty attractive. IMO, with pension funds and insurance companies looking for higher yield on their portfolio, I think that this may be one of the larger pressures on the Intel stock price that keeps it "range bound".

Message.Title: MS Surface Pro is significant
Message.Msg: IDC reported Q2 PC (traditional) shipment dropped from 85.3 million units to 75.6 million units. IDC also reported that MS Surface Pro in Q1 sold over 900,000 units. This means the MS Surface Pro, by itself, managed to offset 10% of the traditional PC drop. With "more than 50 different two-in-one devices in the pipeline, including the very first fanless Core design", we could very well see these newer devices more than offset any traditional PC drop in the coming quarters. Stacey Smith, Intel's CFO "I think what we are seeing is the PC market reinventing ifself"

Topic.Title: Apple and TSMC

Message.Msg: I am not sure I agree. The Apple product lines use their own proprietary OS and software. No other companies share that SW. If Apple puts their ARM based products on Intel process, won't they be compatible with other Intel subsystems and Apple be a potential customer for those? Intel could build the Apple chips in exchange for Apple using Intel LTE and Intel .... If Intel agrees, that would improve the possibility (make it easier for Apple to convert) to an instruction set switch later on. They can plan the SW conversion and convert in a controlled fashion. As for the TSMC statement about 20%, if I were Apple and I had decided to go TSMC, the accounting of Apple revenues would likely be isolated from the future books until it is formally announced. TSMC could be just allocating a "fab" to Apple and not part of its process mix. The capital to finance the fab could even be laundered through Apple if they wanted to keep it quiet. The real curiosity is why Intel is building out the larger than needed fab capacity. Intel would not do that without a solid reason.

Message.Msg: "TSMC 28nm is the most successful foundry node on record in regards to ramp and revenue." I would expect that the TSMC 28nm node is the most successful foundry node by far by revenue. How would you compare the "most successful foundry ramp on record" with the Intel ramps? 32nm? 22nm? Topic.Title: Intel: Major Catalyst Coming On July 22

Message.Msg: I cannot stress this enough, but there is a major upside catalyst coming for Intel (INTC) on July 22. When I checked Intel's investor relations site for any upcoming events, I saw the following: Reimagine the Datacenter 07/22/13 -8:00 AM PT Speaker: Diane Bryant, SVP, General Manager, Datacenter and Connected Systems Group While this seems innocent enough, and for most investors it may not appear to be of consequence, I believe that on this webcast Intel will be announcing its next generation micro-server and networking infrastructure parts based on the Silvermont core known as Avoton and Rangeley, respectively. I believe that many investors are completely unaware of the magnitude of these launches, particularly as the sell side has remained mum in light of their promotion of ARM Holdings' (ARMH) data-center aspirations. These launches will dramatically change the investing landscape, and I will detail why in this article. From Ashraf Eassa
